results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel features the family at Carrum beach in Victoria. We see some great examples of swimsuits at the time as well as women’s suits and hats and a boy in a kilt. The reel ends with scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 begins with two women and a boy walking through sandy bush to the beach, smiling at the camera
00:00:36:00 father and son atop an upturned boat on the beach, posing and waving for the camera
00:00:35:00 the boy running along the sand toward the camera
00:00:45:00 woman running from a bathing box along the sand, stopping briefly for the camera where we see her wearing a knotted headscarf, typical of the day, as a bathing cap
00:01:30:00 man drying himself post swim
00:01:35:00 example of a halter neck one piece women’s swimwear of the era
00:01:57:00 scenes of bushland before we see people picking blackberries
00:02:40:00 a child stares at the camera
00:02:45:00 two older women wearing suits and felt hats typical of the era, sitting on a car running board, one knitting
00:03:00:00 the family group are playing for the camera before playing in a park
00:03:35:00 group picnic around the cars so the running boards can be used as seats
00:04:40:00 riverside stroll with terrier dog
00:05:07:00 backyard cricket practice
00:06:00:00 young boy in kilt and cap with mother in stylish suit and shoes of the day
00:06:11:00 scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel is of the filmmaker’s daughter Jean and her visitor, Toddy. Toddy is in military uniform when he rounds a corner of a house to chat happily to Jean, with their dog and pet birds. While on leave from the RAF, Toddy was billeted to the family home in Essendon during his time in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:01:00 Toddy enters the frame from a side path of to visit Jean at her home
00:00:12:00 Jean leans out the window to chat to Toddy
00:00:16:00 Toddy enthusiastically welcomes a dog into the scene
00:00:20:00 Jean presents two pet birds on her arm for the camera

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander (Alex) Nicoll (1898–1968) grew up in Princes Hill in Melbourne.

As a young man, and after working in various capacities, Alex met wealthy business owner Arthur Thomas who assisted him into business running an import agency at Tasmania House in Flinders Lane. Alex would enjoy a lifelong involvement with Melbourne’s ‘rag trade’ (clothing business) in Flinders Lane, including serving for some years as the President of the Victorian Softgoods Association.

In the 1930s Alex inherited an Agfa 16mm camera, projector and collapsible screen from Arthur Thomas who had been a keen photographer, and over the 1940s and 1950s would capture wonderful moments around Melbourne such as the celebrations for the 1956 Olympics and visits to the beaches of Port Phillip Bay.

After Alexander died, his son Mac continued the family filming enthusiasm in the 1960s and 1970s. Around 2005, the Nicoll family decided to donate most of their collection of films to ACMI.

This reel captures a military parade likely to be sometime in the 1940s down Alexandra Parade, Moonee Ponds and some garden views.

Selected highlight list:

00:00:00:05 a crowd lines the street (most likely Mt Alexander Road near Moonee Ponds Town Hall, the family lived in Essendon)
00:00:00:28 soldiers parade down the street before a crowd of onlookers
00:00:00:51 parade passes a dais on which people stand, one in a mayoral robe and chain of office
00:01:12:00 military trucks and equipment can be seen in the parade
00:01:38:00 soldiers relaxing on the lawn with members of the crowd after the parade

results.title: Las Patronas
results.brief_description: Las Patronas, Mexican women’s group giving food aid to migrants crossing the border
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Las Patronas (The Bosses), a group of Mexican volunteers, have been passing food and water to South and Central American migrants heading to the US border on top of freight trains. This video has been widely shared and celebrated on social media, highlighting the compassion being shown to migrants on the US/Mexico border. Some viewers have questioned if its virality puts the work in danger, but Las Patronas shared the original video to raise awareness and fund their work. According to a 2014 article, the group was formed 19 years earlier, so they’ve been helping people for almost 30 years – far longer than social media has been around. The group was nominated for the Princess of Asturias Award in 2015, after a campaign from Change.org that collected more than 50,000 signatures in support. In a time when Central and South American migration is being used for political stunts in America - like Texas Governor Greg Abbot bussing migrants to Vice President Kamala Harris’ residence on Christmas Eve - Las Patronas depoliticise the media narrative and focus on humanity.

You can find out more about the group on their website (in Spanish) and follow them on Twitter.
description_for_label: Las Patronas (The Bosses), a group of Mexican volunteers, have been passing food and water to South and Central American migrants heading to the US border on top of freight trains. This video has been widely shared and celebrated on social media, highlighting the compassion being shown to migrants on the US/Mexico border. Some viewers have questioned if its virality puts the work in danger, but Las Patronas shared the original video to raise awareness and fund their work. According to a 2014 article, the group was formed 19 years earlier, so they’ve been helping people for almost 30 years – far longer than social media has been around.

results.description: Las Patronas, a group of Mexican volunteer,s have been passing food and water to South American migrants heading to the US border on top of freight trains for many years. This video has been shared widely with some viewers questioning if it’s virality puts the work in danger. However, Las Patronas have their own social media channels to raise awareness and funding for their work.

results.title: Emulation of Mugsy's Revenge for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
As in the original Mugsy this strategy game is presented in a highly visual style with lots of detailed comic-book style stills and short animations. As a gangster in 1919, you see an opportunity to make money by illegally supplying alcohol during the Prohibition era in the US. Hints as to all decisions in the game are given through textual conversations with your assistants - these can include how much booze to produce, how big a bribe to give, and whether to invest in your own Speakeasy bar later on.

Unlike the original game, there are some arcade sequences which involve running around and shooting down the police as they try to arrest you. The character can be hit up to 5 times but it only takes one shot to take out a cop. After each of the game’s 10 years you receive a screen updating you on your progress, as well as a special one if you and your business survives the full decade. [Sourced from https://www.mobygames.com/game/16653/mugsys-revenge//]

results.title: ASL interpreter at Rihanna's Super Bowl performance shines
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of @EyezQueenRF's Tiktok post
results.brief_description: Justina Miles is the first female deaf performer at the Super Bowl’s halftime show. Her joyful ASL (American Sign Language) interpretation of Rihanna’s performance drew much love online. In a press conference the 20 year old said, “I value the opportunity to make it possible for all deaf people to enjoy these songs, and not have them miss out on the full Super Bowl experience.”
results.title_for_label: ASL interpreter at Rihanna’s Super Bowl performance shines
results.description: Justina Miles is the first woman deaf performer at the Super Bowl’s halftime show. Her joyful ASL (American Sign Language) interpretation of Rihanna’s performance drew love from all over the internet. In a press conference the 20 year old said, “I value the opportunity to make it possible for all deaf people to enjoy these songs, and not have them miss out on the full Super Bowl experience.”
description_for_label: Justina Miles is the first woman deaf performer at the Super Bowl’s halftime show. Her joyful ASL (American Sign Language) interpretation of Rihanna’s performance drew love from all over the internet. In a press conference the 20 year old said, “I value the opportunity to make it possible for all deaf people to enjoy these songs, and not have them miss out on the full Super Bowl experience.”

results.title: [Maryborough mudbrick dome]
results.brief_description:
Film showing the construction of a mudbrick hut with domed roof in Maryborough, central Victoria. The hut sits alongside the Maryborough Centenary Reserve, just off Stoneham Drive.

The hut was constructed during a week long workshop with Melbourne arhitecture students and local sustainability enthusiasts including Bill Mollison. The project was featured in ‘The Owner Builder” issue 5 and was overseen by Nepalese architect, Ramesh Manandhar, who is interviewed in the film.

The soundtrack is intermittent.

results.title: Frontline Afghanistan: A Tribute to Raffaele Favero (1945-83)
results.brief_description: A television documentary that pays tribute to Italian born camera operator, Raffaele Favero, who was killed while filming the war in Afghanistan. The film is also a very intimate account of the effect of his death on his wife and children in Australia.
results.title_for_label: Frontline Afghanistan: A Tribute to Raffaele Favero (1945-83)

results.title: DIGGERMODE
results.brief_description:
“Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction and storage, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind-the-servers look into how memory works within platform capitalism.”

“DIGGERMODE” questions the social and environmental ethics of technology in constructing, storing and sharing our images, whether in surveillance databases, museum archives or online. With artificial intelligence (AI), Joel Sherwood Spring has created landscapes in the style of acclaimed Arrernte artist Albert Namatjira being torn apart by mining machinery, and has trained another AI to answer questions like “Who’s your Mob?” Presumably, anyone could do this – but should anyone be able to appropriate Indigenous art from the internet? How do we protect our knowledges in digital spaces? Can sand used to make silicon microchips contain memories of Country?

Joel’s work confronts the viewer with uncomfortable and overlooked aspects of our hyper-networked age, grounding the possibilities of ‘the cloud’ and AI in the broader context of ongoing colonisation. The work considers the environmental damage caused by new technology and data storage, and how it is Indigenous peoples whose lands and ways of being are profoundly impacted by capitalism’s extractive processes.

constellations_primary.name: Extraction
constellations_primary.description: Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind the scenes investigates how memory works within platform capitalism.

constellations_other.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_other.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

Videographer: Akil Ahamat

Script advisor: Enoch Mailangi

Sound production: Bridget Chappelle
